u_shaped_ranking.core_sentence: Higher temperature increases oxidation rates of mercury in the atmosphere, leading
u_shaped_ranking.context_window: The volatility and long-range transport properties of mercury make it particularly sensitive to climate change and effects of climate. Higher temperature increases oxidation rates of mercury in the atmosphere, leading to changes in deposition patterns, more forest fires increase the release of mercury from terrestrial soils, and increased precipitation can lead to higher depositions generally.

u_shaped_ranking.context_window: to changes in deposition patterns, more forest fires increase the release of mercury from terrestrial soils, and increased precipitation can lead to higher depositions generally. These criteria have also been used in the annually recurring CEMP assessments since 2010.
